posts.title: Plain work edges
posts.description: This Capsule explains what plain work edges are, their variety and their history.

pill.title: Content
pill.content:
1.  What are flat work edges?
    1.1.  Identity and expression of the plainsman.
    1.2.  Historic context
2.  Categorization of flat work edges
    2.1.  Milking song
    2.2.  Winch song
    2.3.  Candle song
    2.4.  Whistles, screams and calls
3.  Chants of plain work as Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
Llanera culture revolves around livestock and all related activities. Although rural, urban and semi-urban inhabitants from different regions coexist in the current plains and, although historically in the region there have also been exchanges between Andean peasants, llaneros, various indigenous groups and settlers from different places, the plains have maintained their cultural unity thanks to livestock and it has been she who has given identity to the region together with a very own attitude towards work, as the epicenter not only of economic life but also of the way in which the llaneros perceive the world.

The llaneros, who have always highly valued hard work, honesty and a very close relationship with the landscape and animals, sang to proclaim that they were present and that the plains, despite their immensity, were their domain at the same time as its source of life. The songs announced respect for nature, at the same time as the triumph over the difficulties of livestock life. To these satisfied

Songs of "herding" or "cabrestero" were added others such as those of "candle" that were sung during the nights to keep calm the cattle that used to get nervous when the rain fell on the plain and the thunder was heard.

pill.title: What are flat work edges?
pill.content: The a cappella songs around cattle are characterized by their musical and expressive dimension that reaffirms the llanero spirit, pride and lover of their territory, of the animals they care for and guide. Present in the Llanos and Colombia and Venezuela. The songs are a cultural practice of vocal communication that account for the deep and intimate dialogue of the plains communities with nature, creating territorial and symbolic links manifested in oral language and musicality.

gallery.title: Documentary of working songs from the plain

pill.title: Identity and expression of the plainsman
pill.content:
The llanero has preserved throughout history his love and his passion for the land where he was born. The events and experiences have been the reason to unite the past and the present of the woman and the plainsman with the daily life, which he updates through the experiences that arise from there.

This identity experience of the plainsman is not constructed from a purely external perspective, that is, not only from the experiences acquired through physical contact in daily work, but also intrinsically complements it through the founding component supplied to the majority of Colombian cultures: oral tradition. This factor of orality will account for the immaterial wealth that throughout history the grandparents have bequeathed to the men born in these lands. In this way, an experience is formalized in a radical way through the experiences of a true llanero. This oral tradition has been expressed in many ways, whether through legends, myths, mystery stories, or anecdotal events.

Llano work songs are vital to characterize the llanero man in his behavior, his way of relating to nature, with others and with the transcendent. Due to the particularity of this tradition of the plain work songs, the development of this peasant work has become an expression in danger of extinction like many species of animals, because with the passage of time, it has been drastically confronted with the progress of industry, machines, technology, etc., resulting in the weakening of this tradition.

However, for some llaneros this has not been an impediment in their being and daily work, because their work, be it that of a milker, a cabrester, even that of a calf (children who begin with this traditional milking trade) have symbolized their reason for being, rooted in the customs and traditions of their ancestors.

gallery.title: Animated video about working edges of the plain

pill.title: Historic context
pill.content:
Cattle reached the South American continent through the Spanish and the first cattle entered what is now Colombian territory through Santa Marta in 1525, to later spread and reproduce exponentially in various regions of the country, with sometimes even disproportionate success.

The exhaustive exploration of the Orinoquía by the fervent seekers of El Dorado in the 16th century, was presented as a unique opportunity for cattle ranching as it involved the "discovery" of the Eastern Plains. The plains of the region then baptized with the name of San Martín (which today includes the territory between the Meta and Guaviare rivers) and of Casanare, became giant cattle ranches that completely transformed the landscape and culture of the region. One of the biggest changes that occurred in the plains landscape, due to the promotion of the colonization of the region, was the opening of very extensive trails through which muleteers began to travel who risked their lives transporting, through treacherous and slippery roads. The cattle trails thus became the first commercial route that linked the prosperous and urban area of ​​the altiplano with eastern Colombia.

During the sixteenth century and well into the eighteenth, livestock farming that was practiced in the plains was extensive, which means that it was based on the use by cattle of vast areas of the plains that were used as a common good and in where the animals were controlled and led through jobs such as winching and rodeo to be traded and harnessed once a year.

In the plains of yesteryear there were no fences or limits between the herds or foundations and the only divisions that counted were natural ones such as rivers or streams. The savannah was considered the property of everyone and you could own the cattle, but not the land.

gallery.title: Men with cattle in black and white

pill.title: Historic context
pill.content:
In the era of extensive livestock farming, the landscape had not been transformed in such a radical way as that which can be seen in the current plains, since forage was used much more carefully, and even the animals themselves were different from their contemporaries: after several For generations, the different classes of European cattle had interbred, producing new breeds - better adapted to the Savannah conditions, although also more nervous and difficult to control.

These races are known as the Creole or Casanareña. At the same time, many animals had returned to their wild state, thus appearing the bighorn cattle that occupied the savannah and that whoever domesticated and later marked could consider their property. This was, in elementary terms, one of the "Laws of the Plain", according to which the land belonged to everyone and the free cattle could be taken by whoever had the ability to do so.

While livestock was consolidating as the predominant commercial activity, an enormous cultural change occurred between the early colonization of the 16th century and the rise of livestock at the end of the 17th century, represented by the processes and conflicts that resulted in the strong integration of the cultures of various indigenous groups with the cultural expressions of the new settlers from the interior of the country.

Music, and especially song, turned out to be the common denominator of all the groups involved in the colonization of the Eastern Plains. When, for example, the Society of Jesus arrived in the region in the seventeenth century with intentions of acculturation and evangelization, its main tool to gain the confidence of the inhabitants of the region was the establishment of music schools in which even to make the instruments themselves - taking advantage of the artisan inclination of almost all the llaneros - and then go on to play and sing Christian hymns with their accompaniment.

pill.title: Historic context
pill.content:
Music as a unifying activity was the product of its importance in the region, even before the arrival of the first settlers. In some of the work songs that can still be heard, it is possible to detect melodies similar to the songs of indigenous groups such as the Sikuani, which were sung in the plains since time immemorial. With the arrival of the first Europeans came the Andalusian melismas that had distant origins in refined Arab songs and also the first instruments such as vihuelas, small guitars that would end up becoming enormously popular throughout the region and that even used to accompany the muleteers on their journeys. as recently as the middle of the 19th century. But perhaps the most important instrument was one that the Jesuits introduced and without which llanera music is inconceivable: the harp.

The Jesuits managed to spread music to such a degree among the indigenous and Creole population that after their expulsion in 1767 the music never stopped and the manufacture of instruments became an important artisan work in the region. Absent the priests, the melodies of their hymns were slowly transforming - even in the absence of instruments, since many songs, including work songs, are sung a cappella that told proverbs, sayings and stories about the life of the plains.

The plains have changed a lot and today they continue to change day by day, but the beautiful sound typical of the region -manifested not only in the music but also in the natural sounds, the japeos and whistles, the a cappella songs and the sounds of work- it has remained a strong constant. The work songs emerged as the most essential and unadorned manifestation of that mestizo atmosphere in which music has always been a precondition for being able to be part of social life.

The work songs, which were not accompanied by instrumental music, were strongly attached to the sounds and vocabulary of the llaneros chores, they were positioned as the most primordial of musical expressions, the product of a vital impulse linked to work, to life in the immensity of the savannas and the oral tradition of a group of dissimilar cultures that finally, despite their differences, found a meeting point in an immense shared territory.

However, this harmony is seriously threatened and with it the work songs.

The reason why cattle are no longer sung in the plains is clear from the total change that has occurred in the plains world that gave rise to them, since that world that overflowed with music of nature, which inspired countless poetic images about the immensity of the natural world and in which a particular vocabulary dedicated to livestock was used, sadly no longer exists.

Those who previously traveled the plains and sang to their cattle are already very old and having been stripped of their old way of life, they have also been stripped of all authority against the new economic, cultural and social order that has been superimposed on force. on which used to belong to them as llaneros.

pill.title: Categorization of the working edges of the plain
pill.content:
The tradition given by the ancestors of the llaneros, clearly show today that their customs are still very latent in their hearts and in reality.

The milking songs become a daily sharing with the animals every day of the year. However, it should be noted that, at Easter, mainly on Thursdays and Fridays, these tasks are suspended, since the grandparents of those times, who professed the Catholic faith, gave them to understand that, if these days milking is done, all the milk will turn into blood. On the other hand, this work is carried out by all the members of the family without any distinction of age or sex. The reason is clear, the women participate in the preparation of the cheese together with the girls of the house; While the men take care of the animals, the boy is dedicated to sending the calves to the milker (the father) and the latter in turn brings him closer to the cow so that she can release the milk, in addition to milking the animals, he had to sing softly to him the "put on ... put on my cow." Another aspect that should be highlighted in this work at dawn is the "hidden" verses. These consisted of an exchange of words that took place between the calf and the milker, which consisted of the calf guessing the particular features of the cow, from the sung couplet that the milker improvised. In this way, the child responded with the exact name of the cow, without the danger of being wrong.

The following verse is part of the composition of the Venezuelan Simón Díaz, entitled: “Canto de mildeño” 20.

Milking:
Up there on that hill
I have a clear water well
Where the Virgin is washed
Her little feet and her face.

Calf:
Water cloud, water cloud, water cloud!

The division of labor is not absolute, but commonly the children take care of the calves - acting as calves - while the adults milk. With very tame cows the children have the opportunity to learn and practice milking. At the same time they intervene by linking, managing and arranging the calves; and, in the afternoons, herding pal mamanto.

The 2015 Latin Grammy, the maestro Reynaldo Armas captures it in one of his songs entitled: “When you are big”

When you grow up, look at what I intend to give you
a horse so that you learn to ride,
that is gentle that does not need spurs
of good rein and that he attends by the muzzle.

You will have to choose size and color yourself
that always shows a lot of grace when walking,
that horse will be more than your mount
faithful companion and a friend in particular.

pill.title: Categorization of the working edges of the plain
pill.content:
Winch song

Another aspect that accounts for the llanero's own identity is found in dairy farming. And it is precisely in this place, where the man born in these lands sings to the cattle to be able to guide them to other herds or farms.

Although, this song is a connection of man with animals, and not an interpretation given after reading a music book or some manual for its respective realization. It should be understood that this way of singing arises through an improvised verse, which is not accompanied by any instrument.

Also, this song is known as "herding or cattle", this expression of the culture of the plain, appears in the context of plain work, which consists of being attentive to all activity with livestock. Furthermore, he is in charge of collecting and setting aside, to sell or to work in the corral where the cattle lots are located.

¨The flat work is carried out twice a year, at the beginning and end of winter, in the months of April - May and November - December, and it is always necessary to have an organized group of workers. The plain works are under the direction of a foreman, saquero or commission agent, who designates the positions depending on whether it is work in the sheet or cattle drive; a caprestero, ear flaps, culateros, chocotero, caballicero, etc.¨

Going into details about each of these functions that the flatwork has, it can be implied in the first place, that the Culatero is the rider in charge of lowering the cattle, a different task from that of the winch, since it is pointing (guiding) the cattle to their destination. "The butt" has the task of not letting any animal remain from the herd. Other riders are the ear-eaters: their job consists of being aware of the sides of the livestock; they will not allow the cattle to disperse from the group, but they are in charge of the order to side and side of the cattle lot. For his part, the Caballicero, as his name indicates, is the one who is solely and exclusively responsible for taking care of the horses used in this demanding job, he will be in charge of leading the horses from the corral to the paddocks to graze, he checks them that they are not have slaughter (name that refers to the peeling on the back of the beasts, caused by sweat and implement) and is aware of bathing them in addition to checking the hooves of each of the horses. And finally, there is the Chocotero who was in charge of the details such as food, accommodation for the riders, etc., in the long journeys that were made when livestock were kept.

pill.title: Categorization of the working edges of the plain
pill.content:
Next, an example of the caprestero song is presented in which the experiences lived by the llanero are highlighted, and which are intentionally expressed to guide the cattle.

Shake up little bull, follow the caprestero song., Jooooo, joooo,
that we are going to Guadualito,
to change for money.
My wife and my horse died at the same time., Jooooo, joooo,
my wife God forgive her,
my horse is what I feel.
The steers ask me where the bull died, gacho, gacho, joooo, joooo,
in the royal pass of Apure,
At the foot of a quebrajacho.

Unlike the milking song, the caprestero has the possibility of spreading through the savannah everything that the llanero feels and thinks. In addition to being accompanied by whistles and screams. These songs do not have any rhythmic figure either.

pill.title: Categorization of the working edges of the plain
pill.content:
Candle song

The songs of candle are a tradition that has been lost very quickly, because no llanero sings to the cattle to keep them awake. This song is particular, due to the fact that it is sung throughout the night and part of the morning, in addition to being very important in the tasks of the plain work. This song was sung when the herd of cattle reached a specific point, which was already prepared by "el Chocotero."

In this way, the cattle were led to the corrals during the night, but there was a risk that they would fall asleep, and there the problem began. Any noise put these animals on alert, this event alarmed the cattle and they ran the risk of shuffling, that is, stampeding out, finished in their wake, with all the corrals that the herd had. Precisely, the caporal was in charge of delegating laborers or watchmen to take care of the cattle, and it was through the singing of the candle that the animals calmed down, preventing them from falling asleep, and then with some unexpected noise inside the corral they would wake up and leave terrified to the savannah.
It should be clarified that there was not always a corral of passage, generally the horsemen surrounded the cattle lot, watching over them throughout the night between the humor of the horse and the sound of songs. Finally, the objective of this song was precisely to keep the cattle awake, awake, in that all the llaneros who carried out this type of work agree and in this way avoid a shuffle, a violent departure of the cattle at midnight.

Between themselves they took turns working between the cousin and the early morning, that is to say, that at midnight they handed over the shift so that the second would take charge until the early morning of the day. As long as the cattle were kept awake, there was no possibility of wasting time in the early morning to fetch them.

The following verses correspond to an example of candle singing, with them it will be possible to better understand the context and intention of these songs, since they contain a reality and a narrative of their own for these hours of the night.

To the night watchman who does not sing he wins or shuffles
And he's going to come out with the tale that the devil was to blame.
Don't fuck around, wake up let's go, let's go, let's go ...

Japa vaca, japa bull, japa the bull paints' o
That we are dawning, let's go to town 'or
Aaaaaaa, aaaaaa, aaaaaa
Ouu! Haa! Ouuu!

pill.title: Categorization of the working edges of the plain
pill.content:
Whistles, screams and calls.

Linked to the activity of milking and other aspects of the work of the plain, in these ways of making sounds there are a series of actions that emphasize the possibility of carrying out this work with more skill, we are talking about the whistles and the calls as forms of training, which will serve for the domestication of animals in the livestock environment of said work.

All these reasons are linked to the passing of history, since these whistles and calls were fundamental at a time when the caprestero found it difficult to continue singing, due to the long day of singing during the day.

That is why these two components of flat work were taken as help tools to collaborate with the rest of the rider; In addition, they were suitable for those llaneros who did not have the ability to sing.

For their part, the calls consisted of the rider taking the name of an animal, such as "Cloud of water" and making it repetitive for a long time, until the horse moved to where it was named by the person. "The calls are also a resource that the llaneros use to establish communication with the animals, not only with the cattle, the call to salt, called pal corral, call the pigs to the pigpen, call the dogs."

pill.title: Llano work songs as Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity
pill.content:
Types of heritage.

Among the types of heritage are those that are material and immaterial as a set of tangible and intangible assets that make up the inheritance of a group of people, which the ancestors captured and today are seen as symbols of protection and admiration and that they identify a community.

Intangible heritage.

It refers to a set of traditions that are manifested in technical ways such as: knowledge, expressions, representations, together with the instruments, objects, artifacts and cultural spaces that are inherent to communities or groups and in some cases individuals recognize as an integral part of its cultural heritage. It can also be said that intangible heritage is a way of instilling feelings of feelings that allows identifying the identity of people or groups of people and likewise these are infused from generation to generation by the communities.

pill.title: Llano work songs as Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity
pill.content:
Oral traditions and expressions.

Including language, performing arts, social uses, rituals and festive events, knowledge and uses related to nature and the universe, traditional artisan techniques, Chang (2010) states: Intangible heritage is also formed by all oral traditions, such as music, dance, theater, craft techniques, parties, culinary arts, traditional medicine, among others. This heritage includes ancient knowledge and knowledge, whose origin is lost in the memory of the peoples, since it implies practices, rituals and conceptions of the world with values ​​and symbols that have passed from one town to another and from one generation to another. In the course of history, they have been transformed, re-interpreted and re-created in a collective process, in accordance with the vicissitudes suffered in the natural and social environment.
In other words, intangible heritage are all those intangible aspects that have an important value for a community and that for this reason must be recovered and must not be lost, in a certain way it is the representation that comes from antiquity, which represents a locality as such.

Unesco.

United Nations Organization for Education, Science and Culture UNESCO was created in 1945 to respond to the firm idea of ​​nations, since the agreements they had 24 were not enough to build a lasting peace where new policies were needed to govern for the good of communities, According to Unesco, World Heritage (2018): That there is intercultural understanding Through the protection of heritage and support for cultural diversity. UNESCO created the concept of 'World Heritage' to protect places of exceptional universal value. That progress and scientific cooperation continue and that ties between countries be strengthened. That freedom of expression be protected as it is an essential condition for democracy, development and human dignity.

The working songs of the plains.

The United Nations Organization has already declared as intangible heritage of humanity the work songs of the plains of Colombia and Venezuela, which are a factor of great importance and difference in these places. It is about musically nostalgic and sentimental verses that have a slow beat where many times the best choirs of the joropo have emerged, it is a recognized and typical rhythm of the eastern plain, Unesco says (2018):
“This is perfectly in tune with the dynamics of nature and the environment in this region. The songs narrate vicissitudes of the individual and collective life of the llaneros and are normally transmitted to children from their infancy ”.

In other words, the inhabitants found in the Colombian-Venezuelan Orinoquía developed four types of Work Songs: Milking songs, Cabrester songs, Sail songs and Domestication songs (whistles, screams, calls, japeos ).

He explained the love they have for the work of plain singing in cattle, According to Quiceno (2018):
“The songs are the way in which we llaneros learned to manage livestock, both in the milking pen and in large herds or rodeos. It is the manifestation with which we communicate with the animal, for example, in milking the cow learned to become familiar with our song, with the name we put it and in the herding, the animal responded to the song, obeying the voice of the caprestero , they recognize it ”.

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know…

Some scholars from the region came to the Ministry of Culture of the Republic of Colombia, so that the singing of candle is recognized and in turn the work of plain is introduced in the representative list of the cultural heritage of the national scope. This initiative was approved on January 8, 2014, and it states that the sail edges have "a level of critical risk that cannot be mitigated" and within their observations it is established that "the sail edges are part of the memory of the inhabitants of the region. Currently, the presence of corrals and technical rooms do not make sailing activity necessary, therefore, it is considered that a memory work should be carried out on this type of song aimed at recording and disseminating it.

posts.title: Llanera Traditional Cuisine
posts.description: This capsule explains the term gastronomy, the history and the roots of traditional Llanera cuisine.

pill.title: Content
pill.content:
1. What is gastronomy and gastronomic culture?
2. Characterization of the gastronomy of the Orinoquía
3. Food routines of the region
4. Dishes based on animal protein.
    4.1. Llanera meat
    4.2. Pisillo
    4.3. Creole stuffed
    4.4. Creole Hayaca
5. Doughs and snacks
    5.1. Rice tungo
    5.2. Bastimento
    5.3. Gofios
    5.4. Honeymesabe
6. Drinks
    6.1. Majule
    6.2. Guarrús
7. Indigenous cuisine
    7.1. Derivatives of cassava braca
    7.2. Tatuco

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
Cuisine in the Orinoquia region is a joyous exercise of tradition and sensitivity, influenced above all by a deep-rooted, mystical, mystical, traditional, peasant and indigenous culture that impacts the entire region. Its delicacies could be compared to the best delicacies in the world, melted in the heat of a Creole stove.

But this cuisine could not be so exquisite, without the ancestral influence of the Amazon region, in which wild fruits, seeds, exotic plants, fish and the generous, abundant and grateful yucca abound; the latter, constituted as the common food and the plant par excellence for the Huitotos, Muinane and Makuna ethnic groups, among others, settled in the departments of Caquetá and Putumayo and in the savannas of Alto Cahuinarí, mainly, in whose enjoyment a good part of community life.

The ways of cooking, which range from cultivating, selecting, cutting and seasoning, to boiling, serving and sharing, reveal cultural, social and conjunctural categories, determined by reasons of geography, climate, access routes and location, among other aspects. Food is what determines the role of men and women in society and within the family, depending on their social organization.

The potential of food culture in the region is nurtured through the "power of the word" and that of ancestral belief to counteract flavors and effects, to mitigate pain, generate life, increase desire, elevate the spirit, call fertility and "raising the dead," as it is popularly expressed in the region when someone is dying or has a hangover.

gallery.title: Women in traditional costume and mamona

pill.title: What is gastronomy and gastronomic culture?
pill.content:
Gastronomy.

Gastronomy is the discipline that studies the relationship between culture and food during a certain period of time. The term is born from the union of two Greek words: gastros (stomach) and nomos (knowledge). In a strict sense, its object is culinary art, the relationship between preparing, serving and consuming food. While Jean Anthelme says: “Gastronomy is a knowledge, an understanding, especially what has to do with food. Its objective is to ensure the survival of humanity thanks to a tasty and adequate diet ”.

Gastronomic culture.

In the Ministry of Culture of Colombia, Ángela Caro recognizes that gastronomic culture is the ingenuity, knowledge and flavor of cooks who make the past dialogue with the present, recreating preparations whose origin is lost in time and merging them with new knowledge, because traditional cuisine as a cultural manifestation is dynamic and evolves day by day. Likewise, In the work of Leyva and Gómez (as he quotes Sonia Montecino (2009) "cuisine and culture may well be synonymous. Understood as language, the web of human nutrition throws us into a dense matter in which the body, the Techniques and symbols intertwine to produce a warp in different societies. This author proposes us to see society through a fundamental activity, such as food, and how it creates a set of unique characteristics linked to the way to organize and prepare food".

pill.title: Characterization of the Llanera gastronomy
pill.content:
In the Colombian Orinoquía region, with the exception of the culinary customs of the indigenous people, the gastronomy usually has different flavors in the same dish. The sweet and sour, bittersweet, spicy and acid flavors predominate by the combination of fruits with meats, pisillos (combination of beef, pork, chicken, chigüiro and mamona), herbs, seeds, sauces, broths and various kinds of chili. The contrasts in the food that balance the flavors and effects are very prominent, both in the indigenous peoples and in the rest of the inhabitants.

An example of the above is the case of coca, conceived as a vehicle of heat that, combined with something cold and pacifying like tobacco, manages to maintain balance to acquire "the power of the word." The foregoing also applies to the case of seeds, fruits, legumes and meats that, mixed with seasonings such as chili pepper and salt, acquire not only a different flavor, but also new meanings in the culinary world.

The indigenous peoples of the Orinoco and the Colombian Amazon classify food according to appearance, taste and texture; This is the case of hard and soft foods: the former associated with the masculine, such as cassava, due to their hardness and rigidity, and the latter, feminine, such as fariña, casabe or manioc, the result of the preparation of cassava to be consumed. In this last aspect, the fact of passing through female hands for consumption is striking. The sweet and the strong do not exactly refer to the flavors, but it has a more symbolic connotation because it relates the sweet with something calm and good. In the same way, strong is related to bravery and pain. For the natives, the cultivated plants are sweet (sajari) and are identified as female labor and the animals that come from hunting and fishing are strong (junirise), seen as male labor. That feminine side in the regions of the Amazon and the Colombian Orinoquía is the largest producer of food, since it is women who are the "mothers of food" who maintain the cultivation of products such as yucca, pineapple, yam, chontaduro, caimarona grape, among others. . It is the space of relationship with spiritual beings and also with other groups.

In some places in this region, the cuisine continues to represent culture and tradition, being very peasant and ancestral; However, a good part of this has been affected by globalization, a situation that is reflected in the presence of chemicals in food, hormones, artificial flavors, synthetic or industrialized wines. Eating habits are believed to be one of the most resistant cultural aspects to changing the acculturation process, because that knowledge becomes a form of cultural identity, which shows that the act of eating is not exclusively a biological and nutritional phenomenon, it is also a social expression of culture.

An example of this is the comparison between the culinary traditions of the city man with those of the peasant. The vigor and resistance of the men of rural life, to face the attacks of the environment is greater, compared with that of the city man who consumes junk food, precooked and canned, among others. In a generalized way, the inhabitants of the southeast of the country consume vegetables, grains, legumes, fruits and meats, components of a balanced diet, in addition to having a good physical activity due to their hunting, planting, fishing and livestock activities.

In the Orinoquía, soups, boiled and sancochos accompanied by a main dish such as fish meat and pisillos, as well as delicate desserts, sponges and jellies, make up a plains menu par excellence.

As a llanero is, it is the gastronomy of the region; bittersweet, spicy, intoxicating, strong and well "trancao" for the "parrando". It's like a shot of Majule (a highly intoxicating fermented drink) or like a red-hot stove. The Venezuelan writer Rómulo Gallegos already expressed it in his novel Doña Bárbara: The plain goes crazy and the madness of the man of the wide and free land is always to be a ranger ... At work: taming and browsing, which are not jobs, but recklessness ; at rest: the plain in the malice of the "chunk", in the beauty of the "passage", in the sensual melancholy of the copla; in lazy abandonment: the immense land ahead and not walking, the horizon all open and looking for nothing.

The unique llanera culture, halfway between the horse and the canoe, eats to live, but also lives to eat. Their activities are dominated by livestock, hunting and fishing influenced, most of the time, by the Amazon region from which they inherit a large amount of wild fruits, seeds and jungle plants.

pill.title: Food routines of the region
pill.content:
A typical breakfast in the departments of the Colombian Orinoquia, begins with a good cerrero coffee around 4:00 a.m. When the long journey begins It is very common for the table to taste the famous cachapa, a sweet corn arepa or jojoto with cheese and majule con leche.

Depending on the appetite and the conditions, another option to enjoy a good breakfast is to enjoy a pericade of turtle, seagull or sometimes heron eggs. The fondness for animals is inherited from the indigenous peoples, who obtained eggs or sometimes turtle meat for the Spanish.

These parakeets can be accompanied with rice bread, a food that soaked in cereal and milk obtained from milking, generates rolls to accompany any meal, especially guarulo, a light coffee sweetened with panela that is taken in the morning. Fish broths or stews are essential when it comes to tasting a “locked” breakfast; However, in the region there is a very particular culinary tradition and they are the common "pisillos". The "pisillado", as it is known in the region, is nothing more than a mince of beef mainly, cut into thin strips, much desired by its inhabitants. There are fish as the main breakfast companion, along with a good portion of hogao and achiote oil.

With regard to the broths, the best "raises the dead" after a good "parrando" are the cachama head broths, which provide energy and hydrate the body. The cachama is the most widely consumed Amazonian fish in the plains region. The pioneers and kings of its preparation are in the galleras; When there are festivities or challenges, there is cachama soup for everyone.

But the cachama is not the only king fish of the broths, you can also taste another "raise the dead" with the gamitana or tambaquí, which competes with the cachama in size and quality; the latter wins for its reputation of being the most delicious in the region.

pill.title: Dishes based on animal protein
pill.content:
Llanera meat

The mamona is part of the most popular and typical llanero dish, enjoyed most of the time in a barbecue with indirect heat. It has its origin in the economy, when in the past, in the large herds and social gatherings, the youngest animal was sacrificed because it was the least expensive; however, it had the best flavor and smooth texture for its tender meat. Cassava, banana and fruits in juice or pulp such as carambola, pineapple, chontaduro, copoazu, arara and apple-fruit, mainly, cannot be missing in a llanero barbecue. The types of cut of the mamona for the roast, vary between the ribs, the pulp meat and the meats of the shoulders that are seasoned, most of the time, with salt, beer and spices.

Preparation is slow: three to four hours. Its success consists in avoiding the flames as much as possible and in not sucking the meats so that they do not lose their juices. These dishes are served with potato, banana, yucca, guacamole or hogao and are served on banana leaves.

gallery.title: Carne a la Llanera Meat Dish

pill.title: Dishes based on animal protein
pill.content:
Pisillo

Pisillo is a common preparation that is made mainly with dried beef minced into thin strips. This is cooked until it softens and big and long onion, garlic and paprika are added and it is accompanied with cooked yucca. The pisillo can also be made with fish and bush meats. This is what the popular song says: Tonight I will have dinner with a ´venao´ pisillo.

The pisillo is a dish in which chigüiro, venison, caiman or fish meat is cooked, or birds such as ducks, and then this meat is shredded or ground to be mixed with a stew. The ideal consistency of the pisillo is moist, almost like a pate.

pill.title: Dishes based on animal protein
pill.content:
Creole stuffed

This traditional recipe consists of mixing finely minced meat, minced potato, dried rice, cooked peas, and spices together with the blood to form a uniform filling. Once this preparation is ready, it is stuffed until the guts are filled. They are cooked in boiling water with salt and they are usually pounded with orange thorn to see if no blood comes out, which is a sign that they are ready.

To serve they are fried in pig oil cut into small portions. Accompanied with chili, cooked or fried yucca, cooked mole plantain, plantain in patacón and a delicious guarapo llanero as a drink.

pill.title: Dishes based on animal protein
pill.content:
Creole Hayaca

The region's tamale is called hayaca araucana, a name given to it by the inhabitants of Venezuela, widespread throughout the region. The expression means wrapping, for the mixture of meats and vegetables inside a corn dough, cooked on a banana leaf or bijao. The big difference with other tamales is that inside it has young veal meat or mamona (common in llanero roasts). Among its ingredients are salt, pepper, hogao, red or chirere paprika and cimarrón coriander.

pill.title: Doughs and snacks
pill.content:
Rice tungo

The tungos belong to the great Colombian tradition of the cuisine of those wrapped in leaves, whose most representative dish is the tamale.

These are a sweet cheesy rice dough wrapped in different leaves. In the plains the use of the legue vaca is typical, it is a common plant of the Amazon and the Magdalena river basin. Due to its size and resistance, it has been common in the kitchen, as well as bijao, banana leaves and others. Researchers have counted more than a hundred different leaves used in Colombia to wrap food in cooking processes.

They are prepared with rice, cheese, salt and sweet; wrapped in bijao leaves that give it a special flavor.

pill.title: Doughs and snacks
pill.content:
Bastimento

Traditional snack that contains crunchy slices of green and ripe banana, pieces of fried beef or pork, gofios, pieces of cheese, panela and pork rinds.

pill.title: Doughs and snacks
pill.content:
Gofíos

They are an old tradition in the indigenous llanera slope, they are doughs of toasted and ground corn that accompany the llanero on the long days in the plain. Corn or cassava flours hydrated with water and flavored with honey or chili, constituted the staple food of the indigenous communities of the jungle. The Gofios become creoles with the panela brought by the Spanish. As a basic preparation it allows different variants and can also be made with cooked corn, chocolo corn, yellow corn or white corn, among others.

pill.title: Doughs and snacks
pill.content:
Honeymesabe

Dulce de leche cut, prepared with panela.

pill.title: Drinks
pill.content:
Majule

Also known as chicha de platano, this drink comes from the interior of Casanare, deep in the Eastern Plains, and its main ingredient is topocho (banana). Its origin comes from the indigenous Chiricoas, who consumed it as soup. It became an alcoholic beverage when it was fermented for several days, for which it was stigmatized for a long time because it is said that whoever drinks it goes out of control, causing the instability of the tribe and reaching extreme cases of murdering their own brothers. In moderation, like everything, it's actually a tasty, brotherly drink. You can find it in the festivals of the region such as Canto Sabanero, an international festival that integrates the culture and gastronomy of the llanera.

pill.title: Drinks
pill.content:
Guarrús

Guarrús is known for being a typical drink of the department of -Casanare, it is based on corn, rice and cheese. This is a traditional drink that has been in the department for more than 70 years.

On the other hand, it serves as an accompaniment to the famous barbecue, or after flat work as its characteristic flavor allows diners to enjoy a delicious drink.

pill.title: Indigenous cuisine
pill.content:
Ingredients such as rice, yuca brava, sweet potato, yam, borojó, pineapple, guama, chili pepper, seje, moriche, fruits, chigüiro, cachirre, venison, cachicamo, insects, paujil are found within the food system of the indigenous peoples of the Orinoquía. , squirt, coporo, curito, catfish, caribbean, palometa, guacuco, turtle, bototoy matador. With these ingredients, foods such as Casabe, mañoco, moqueado, ajicero, roasted culonas ants, among others, are produced.

Although indigenous peoples make great use of the natural ingredients they find around them, cassava is perhaps the main ingredient for these communities since it not only represents a tradition transmitted from before the colony by their ancestors but is also largely measure an ingredient that has guaranteed the food sovereignty of these peoples, thanks to the fact that with this ingredient foods such as mañoco and cassava are produced, which are not very perishable.

In addition to the above, it is important to stop at how food, and the spaces in which it is acquired, gain meaning and value among a group of people. Cassava and conuco, for example, speaking in terms of their use value, gain importance in the world of women, and in that of the family sphere, based on the fact that the ability to care for a conuco, make it productive, be able to extract cassava and cassava and mañoco know-how, allow women to put themselves in the position of maintaining a home, of feeding their family.

Derived from the yuca brava.

Mañoco

It is one of the oldest traditional dishes in the Americas; Originally from the indigenous cultures of the American Caribbean, in the eastern plains of Colombia this food this food is part of the almost daily diet of the indigenous people and many of the people of the region.

The process begins by extracting the yucca from the Cocuno (land plot with cultivation), the earth and dirt are removed and transported in the catumare (artisan basket). It is washed with a lot of water and left to rest for three days in clean water. The cassava skin is then scraped with a knife or machete until it is completely clean and washed. All the yuca is scratched until there is a dough of it and previously scratched yuca is added, that dough is left to rest for two days. Then it goes on to the squeezing process; This is done with the Sebucán (indigenous tool to squeeze), here it is squeezed out of all liquid and the yuré (poison). The resulting dry mass is extracted from the sebucán and with a mass or machuca stone until it is converted into flour. It is taken to the budare where it will be left for about an hour, during that period of time it must be stirring the flour at all times, after an hour of withdrawing from the budare and that granulated flour is ready to consume alone or as a companion.

pill.title: Indigenous cuisine
pill.content:
Casabe

This food comes from the indigenous ethnic groups that inhabited and inhabit the Orinoquia region or the eastern plains. Casabe is a bread that is made from a single ingredient, cassava, and contains no sourdough or fat, which gives it a particularly tough and crunchy consistency.

It is shaped like a thin circular cake, of various sizes. It is called casibito when it is 3 or 4 centimeters in diameter and is eaten as a snack. Its slight nutty flavor goes well with savory dishes and sweets.

pill.title: Indigenous cuisine
pill.content:
Tatuco

In one of its delicacies, there is the tatuco, one of the most unique cooking techniques that mixes the tradition of those wrapped in vegetables, with the cooking of the hole in the ground. This tradition, perhaps, is one of the most outstanding and unique, not only in the cuisine of the Orinoquía and the Amazon, but also in the world. It is a slow cooking process in which food is cooked in its own juices. The difference with other stoves is that it is cooked on the ground, after opening a hole of approximately 20cm.

This technique uses the indirect heat of the fire to obtain a slow cooking process. In this way, the tatuco made up of fish or meat, cassava, banana, seasoned vegetables and the ingredients that the cook prefers is introduced, wrapped in bijao or banana leaves, tied with rope or rope. Then, the same earth that was removed is used to cover the hole and a bonfire is lit on top that will burn for approximately two hours. Once the tatuco is unearthed, it must be cleaned very well and served on fresh banana leaves.

In the end you get an exquisite meal. The previous one is one of the most impressive preparations, due to the journey and experience that is needed to open a hole in the ground, introduce a guadua log stuffed with chicken, fish or meat, cover it with banana leaves, light a bonfire and then dig it up for tasting.

question.question: The main ingredient of the majule is?

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know…

Cassava or cassava is free of fat and gluten, as well as rich in fiber and type B vitamins.

posts.title: Antique Instruments
posts.description: To know the etymology and roots of the old musical instruments of the llaneros.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Origin of the Cirrampla
    1.1. Etymology
    1.2. Roots
2. Origin of the Furruco
    2.1. Etymology
    2.2. Roots
3. Origin of Bandolina
    3.1. Etymology
    3.2. Roots

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
The joropo is a musical genre and traditional dance of Colombia and Venezuela.

The joropo is part of the ternary music of the colonial Caribbean, being directly related to the Son Jarocho and Son Huasteco of Mexico, the Mejorana of Panama, among others. These musical expressions developed during the colonial period with influences from Baroque music and inter-oceanic trade.

Until the middle of the 20th century, and as far as the plains region of Venezuela and the Eastern Plains of Colombia are concerned, the word joropo referred to a social event -almost a fair- lasting from a few hours to a whole week. People from the locality or people coming from various places, generally attracted by commercial exchange, participated in the event, where the central event was the music, the dance and the contrapunteos. The music of the joropo llanero was provided by a basic ensemble composed of harp, maracas and singing. If there was no harp, it was substituted by a bandola or violin.

There is also an instrument, although it is on the way to extinction due to lack of players, such as the CIRRAMPLA, which in the time of the violence of the fifties was the only instrument used at night to lull the llaneros to sleep during those difficult times in the Colombian country.

pill.title: Origin of the Cirrampla
pill.content:
Etymology:

Instrument that costs of a wooden stick which has a string tied along, and as a sounding board is used the mouth, vibrating the string with the fingers of the hand. Today it can be considered "extinct" from folklore, since no one teaches its execution anymore and it was used only here in Colombia.

Roots:

The Jesuits begin to teach the Indians to read, write and teach them religion, also to add and something important the Castilian language, among the things that the Jesuits carried there were some instruments for their time as violins, harps triangles, where they teach them to play to the Indians.

It is said that it is an adaptation of the violin by the position in which it is interpreted, it was adapted to a single string and its sound box is the mouth of the interpreter, had its heyday at the time of the war of the fifties (50) when at night should not make noise for fear of attacks by the chulabitas, was the instrument of choice in those sleepless nights and lullaby for many who could not sleep.

pill.title: Origin of Furruco
pill.content:
Etymology:

"Furro" is inferred to refer to a rustic musical instrument. Besides being known by the name of the title, this instrument is also called "furruco".

Roots:

The furruco or furro, is a musical instrument composed of a wooden drum and animal hide, in addition to that it has a wooden rod with a waxed tip which when rubbed from top to bottom produces the sound.

In any case, how does the Furruco sound?

When rubbing this reed with the hands, the vibration is transferred to the drumhead producing a deep sound similar to the roar of an animal. ... Although the function of the furruco in the ensemble is rhythmic accompaniment, the fact that it always resonates the same low note generates a very interesting pedal sound.

You may ask, how is the sound of a drum produced?

A drum is a percussion instrument with an indeterminate sound, belonging to the family of membranophones according to the Hornbostel-Sachs classification system. ... The sound is obtained by striking the instrument on the drumhead with the hand or with drumsticks. The snare is also usually percussed.

How is the furruco made in the following way?

The furruco is a membranophone formed by a cylindrical wooden body. It has a single goat leather drumhead on one of its sides which has a waxed reed attached to it. When rubbing this reed with the hands, the vibration is transferred to the drumhead producing a deep sound similar to the roar of an animal.

pill.title: Origin of the Bandolina "Mandolin".
pill.content:
Etymology:

The mandolin is a stringed instrument with four double orders of strings. The number and type of mandolin strings has varied over time and place, but today the predominant configuration is that of the Neapolitan mandolin, with four double strings tuned like the violin (G-R-A-E).

The mandolin strings are usually plucked with a pick or plectrum, fingers may also be used. The soundboard may be concave or flat.

Roots:

If you've ever seen a country band playing live, you may have noticed someone playing what looks like a small guitar. That instrument is, in fact, a mandolin. The mandolin is a musical instrument in the lute family. It generally has four courses of double metal strings, for a total of eight strings, which are tuned in unison.

Throughout the following millennia, this instrument would be called by many names, before being called the lute. This instrument traveled throughout Europe and the Middle East. In a 14th century painting, a miniature lute is depicted by an angel. This instrument is called the mandola, by the Latins. The Italians, on the other hand, called this instrument the mandolin.

When European immigrants began arriving in North America in the 19th century, they brought the mandolin with them. Due to an interest in strange or exotic things, the mandolin became a popular instrument. The mandolin was popular during the 1850s as a novelty that entertained the middle class. In the late 19th century, there was a surge of Italian immigration that further popularized a version of the mandolin. this instrument would remain popular well into the 20th century, and at one point factories were mass producing it.

The mandolin in the 1940s

By the 1940s, the mandolin, along with the banjo and guitar, had become popular among middle-class youth on college campuses in the American South. During this time, musicians were more experimental in the way they used the instrument.

As a result of this experimentation, new styles of playing emerged, some of which were influenced by techniques that are more closely related to the guitar.

In the llanera music has been making a comeback since some time ago, with some interpreters and due to its particular sonority.

posts.title: Crafts, transformation of materials and llanera identity
posts.description: To know the characteristics and importance of handicrafts in the region.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Transformation of materials and llanera identity
    1.1. Leather work
        1.1.1. Campechanas
        1.1.2. Quote
        1.1.3. Rejos
        1.1.4. Beef chub size
    1.2. Woodworking
        1.2.1. Wood carving
        1.2.2. Taparo carving
    1.3. Weaving work
        1.3.1. Backpack
        1.3.2. Basketry
        1.3.3. Indigenous handicrafts cumare palm, moriche palm
    1.4. Ceramic work

pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content:
The region of the eastern plains of Colombia presents great cultural, gastronomic and musical richness, craftsmanship and diverse customs that become a hallmark of this region.

The handicrafts produced in different materials become a fundamental part of the llanera identity, since they are not only of high quality, but also give us to know the different techniques used for its elaboration, whose final result, provides beautiful pieces made by artisans of the region. I invite you to know the wonderful craftsmanship of Casanare.

pill.title: Transformation of materials and llanera identity
pill.content:
Without a doubt, the llanero is known for his great sense of identity with his region and traditions; he knows how to carve wood, leather, the totumo fruit, the leaves of different types of palms, weave and draw landscapes. Thanks to these skills are made chinchorros, atarrayas, backpacks, maracas, rings, figures of fauna and cotizas that are not only valued nationally, but also have transcended borders internationally.

The maracas made from the fruit of the totumo are the sample of a detailed, functional and quality craftsmanship, made by artisans of the region that generation after generation have kept alive the tradition of the llanera.

pill.title: Leather work
pill.content: Beef leather is used for the production of various handicraft implements in the llanera culture. First the leather is tanned, either "natural", i.e. in the sunlight or through specific chemical and mechanical processes to be able to work it later.

pill.title: Leather work
pill.content:
Some crafts made from leather are:

Campechanas:

They are hammocks made with strips of tanned leather, somewhat rustic, but very traditional in the eastern plains, commonly used for the rest of the llaneros, after his day's work.

The elaboration of the campechanas is a process inherited generation after generation, where skill is required to cut, weave and dye the leather with dyes from seeds and roots, then stretch it and leave it in the sun for a certain period of time for drying and subsequent weaving.

Visually the campechanas are very beautiful handcrafted pieces that show without a doubt the talent of the artisans of the llaneros.

pill.title: Quote
pill.content:
Undoubtedly the cotizas are a fundamental part of the llanero identity, of the traditional attire of the region and can be found elaborated in different materials, mainly leather and in many colors. They are a key piece in the traditional llanero dance, where the couple makes them sound against the floor to the rhythm of a good joropo; they are also mentioned in coplas and songs, for example:


The quotes that I have are made by Mama Pancha
And he sold them to me one night for a night out at the veneer
The soles of my shoes are made of pure leather and wool.
Adorned on top with half silver cigars
I premiered them that night tapping at the foot of the harp
Chamarreando las parejas donde una guacharaca
So savannah admiration in that room so buttery
Where I made them hit the ground mother saintly mother
They even sounded a Pa-ta-tra-tra-tra-tra-tracaTraca-traca

pill.title: Rejos
pill.content: The rejos are traditional for the work of plain and cowherd, are obtained from the leather of cow or steer to come out hard, is dried, twisted and stretched until it is completely dry, then peeled and lard is poured from the same animal from which the leather was obtained until it is ready for use.

pill.title: Beef chunk carving
pill.content:
The carving of beef horn is a very old practice carried out in the eastern plains of Colombia, where all parts of the beef are used, without being an exception the horns that come from the head of the cattle. These are extracted through a cut that removes its pulp, composed of cartilaginous tissue, then dried with lime for a long time in a place where there is no humidity.

For the manufacture of different handcrafted pieces, the horn is initially softened to detach the interior bone part, submerging the piece in water for a while; after this, a greater plasticity of the empty horn is achieved, it is cooked in water or industrial oil until it can be manipulated, sectioned, pressed or cut. The finishing and brightness of the handmade piece is done with sandpaper, emery or polishing machine, until the final product is obtained, which can become a comb, a spoon, a necklace, pieces for jewelry, accessories, plates, rings, chests and bracelets among others.

pill.title: Woodworking
pill.content:
Wood is one of the craft materials par excellence, since it is easily available and plasticity can be made multiple figures, paintings, musical instruments, earrings, furniture and utensils among others.

Wood carving:

Wood carving refers to the technique of carving wood for the elaboration of a sculpture, giving it a specific design or shape according to the creativity of the carver; this is one of the most popular and complex techniques in the world of handicrafts, since there are carvers who can create extremely detailed works that require time, concentration and dedication until the finished piece is obtained.

This noble craft performed by many artisans from the plains gives us a great variety of sculptures, reflecting the rich culture of this region, finding beautiful artistic pieces of wildlife, chairs, decorative elements, characters, murals, window frames and mirrors, couples dancing joropo among others, which make them unique and of unparalleled cultural value.

There are 3 types of wood carving taking into account the level of difficulty in its realization, the first is the simple carving where reliefs or shapes are made without the implementation of many tools; the second is the carving made, which requires more experience and skill to create details, greater reliefs with a realistic touch and more specialized tools are used. Finally, there is the 3D carving, where the artisan must have greater skill in creating pieces with greater depth and so realistic that one comes to doubt that they are made of wood; the implementation of more varied and sophisticated tools are characteristic of this type of carving.

gallery.title: A sculptor who transforms wood into art

pill.title: Taparo carving
pill.content:
Crescentia cujete is a tree commonly known as totumo or taparo, characterized by its fruits of spherical appearance, large and woody shell, which is suspended from the trunk or thicker branches of the tree. Since long ago it has been used to make containers and handicrafts by many llaneros.

From these fruits are made various objects using its shell that is very light, mainly as a container for arequipe or blancmange, as a totuma to drink guarapo or to make decorative objects. Centerpieces, lamps, trays, fruit bowls, earrings, bracelets and carved jewelry are handmade; there are many handicraft options that can be made with this material.

pill.title: Weaving Work
pill.content:
Weaving is considered an artisanal or industrial process where woven fabrics are produced from threads, using some techniques such as loom weaving, knitting, crochet or two-needle weaving. The handicrafts produced by weaving are an activity to which many families in the region are dedicated, some with weaving machines and most with hand looms, giving rise to varied artistic samples.

In the elaboration of handmade woven products, it requires technique and knowledge in the handling and processing of flexible materials that can be braided, twisted or wrapped depending on the need of the handmade piece that is being elaborated.

pill.title: Basketry
pill.content: For the creation of baskets, firm elements are used to be assembled by hand, flat like mats or more frequently in the form of containers. This work consists of the elaboration of objects through the orderly and structured arrangement of semi-hard vegetable materials such as vines, reeds, wicker, leaves, stems and bark. All these materials are previously subjected to processes of adaptation and many are dyed in different colors for later weaving.

pill.title: Backpack
pill.content: In Colombia there are several regions where backpacks are made, most of them are handmade with multiple designs and colors, being the Wayuu backpacks one of the most representative in our country. The most common materials used in the elaboration of a backpack are cotton threads, fique, macramé, cumare palm, moriche palm or wool among others.

gallery.title: origin and meaning of the Wayuu backpack

pill.title: Indigenous handicrafts in cumare palms
pill.content:
The craftsmanship elaborated by the indigenous communities of the region, not only evidences the cultural richness but also the ancestral tradition that continues alive generation after generation.

The cumare palm (Astrocaryum chambira) is distributed in various parts of Colombia and among them the eastern plains, is an important species in the production of fiber thanks to its strength, flexibility and durability, is widely used in the production of handicrafts such as hammocks, bags, necklaces, handles, mats, nets, hats and ropes among others.

pill.title: Indigenous handicrafts in cumare palms
pill.content:
This palm has been used by the Sikuani communities for the elaboration of handicrafts; initially they cut it and extract the fiber, a process that is done manually by the women, then it is washed and cooked with water and lemon, to later bleach it by drying it in the sun. For the dyeing of the fiber are used achiote seeds, saffron, leaves and bark of other plants.

For the weaving of the fibre you can use the flat thread, the twisted thread and various systems or techniques of crossed threads, knots, loom, with heeling needle and with crochet needle.

pill.title: Indigenous handicrafts in moriche palms
pill.content: On the other hand, the moriche palm (Mauritia flexuosa) also known as the tree of life, is a plant characterized by its high ecological value, since for years it has been a source of life for indigenous communities; it has a high nutritional, social, economic and cultural value.

pill.title: Indigenous handicrafts in moriche palms
pill.content: In addition, it provides the necessary material for the elaboration of handicrafts, which in this case are the fibers of moriche, extracted from the buds (young leaves) for the elaboration of hammocks, hats, backpacks, baskets, and fruit bowls among other products made from the ancestral tradition of several indigenous groups.

pill.title: Ceramic Work
pill.content:
The pottery has its roots in ancient times where containers were made to store food and water, there are also records of figures of people, animals, vases, cups, plates and religious objects that are the representation of various cultures throughout the world.

Nowadays the elaboration of ceramic products has evolved in its processes, it includes several techniques of clay manufacture, among them the pottery, where pieces are obtained using the potter's wheel; the furnaces and specialized tools allow better finishes and details in the elaborated ceramics.

To obtain resistant pieces, the clay must undergo processes such as molding, then comes the drying, firing and finally decoration.

question.question: Which of the following handicrafts is made from beef leather?

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

The indigenous communities of Colombia are important producers of handicrafts in our country. For example, the handicraft production of the departments of Caquetá, Guaviare, Meta and Vichada is mainly represented by indigenous communities, which produce approximately 90 per cent of the handicraft production marketed in this region.

posts.title: Water sources and natural reserves.
posts.description: To know the characteristics of the main water sources and natural reserves of the department of Casanare.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Water sources.
    1.1. Casanare River.
    1.2. Yopal: Cravo River.
    1.3. Peanuts: Cusiana River.
    1.4. Peanut: Tinije Lagoon.
    1.5. Tauramena: El Zambo Waterfall.
    1.6. Pore: Pauto river.
    1.7. Villanueva: Arietes Stream.
2. Nature reserve.
    2.1. Aguazul: San Miguel de Farallones.
    2.2. Paz de Ariporo: Zamaricote Hill.
3. Natural reserves of civil society.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content: The geographic location, the varied topography and the climatic regime that characterize the Colombian territory have determined that it possesses one of the greatest hydric offers of the planet. In Casanare one of the main potentialities of the Department is the hydrographic wealth; abundant rivers, streams, lagoons and wetlands (estuaries) form an intricate water network that provides the llaneros with excellent biodiversity of flora and fauna and serves as a means of communication and transportation during the rainy season.

gallery.title: Water and its journey through Casanare

pill.title: Casanare River
pill.content:
The Casanare River begins its source in the Sierra Nevada del Cocuy, west of the department of Arauca, in the Colombian Eastern Cordillera. This lavish torrent of waters creates the border between the departmental localities of Arauca, Casanare and Vichada, where it moves until it reaches the Meta River, to expand its mouth.

Its basin belongs to the Orinoco River Hydrographic Basin, located in the Cravo Norte municipality, in Arauca, and joins the most important and potentially navigable rivers in the region, such as the Meta River, the Cravo Sur River, the Upía River, the Aripoto River, the Cusiana River and the Pauto River.

pill.title: Yopal: Cravo Sur River
pill.content: The Cravo Sur or Cravosur River originates in the municipality of Mongua Boyacá, in the Páramo de Pisba. It is 138 km long and runs through the municipalities of Mongua and Labranzagrande, in the department of Boyacá and Yopal, San Luis de Palenque and Orocué, in the department of Casanare and flows into the Meta River. It is one of the most important and fast-flowing rivers of Casanare, with an average of 151 m 3/s. Due to the relief of high slopes of the riverbed and the deforestation suffered by the constant floods in winter, it has a torrential regime that gives rise to alluvial fans between the foothills and the savannah, as in the case of Yopal.

pill.title: Maní: Cusiana River
pill.content:
The Cusiana River rises on the eastern flank of the Eastern Cordillera in the department of Boyacá. The basin, with an approximate extension of 506,254 hectares, is home to a main stream 271 km long that flows over a wide altitudinal gradient, with the highest elevation at 3,800 meters above sea level and the lowest at 150 meters above sea level, at which altitude it delivers its waters to the Meta River in the jurisdiction of the municipality of Maní in the department of Casanare.

87% of the territory of the Cusiana river basin (439,967.2 ha) extends over the department of Casanare, covering the municipalities of Chámeza, Recetor, Yopal, Aguazul, Tauramena and Maní, all of them, except Yopal, have their municipal seats in the basin and only two, Aguazul and Recetor, are totally included in the territory of the basin. The Department of Boyacá covers 13% of the territory (65,830 ha).

pill.title: Peanuts: Tinije Lagoon
pill.content:
The Tinije lagoon is a strategic ecosystem declared by Corporinoquia Regional District of Integrated Management - DRMI, which houses a great biodiversity in flora and fauna, part of the lagoon is located in the municipality of Aguazul village Graciela and Mani Mararabe village, its water mirror of water covers 128 ha, the lagoon as such has an area of 4 kilometers long, 400 meters wide and a maximum depth of 6 meters in winter time.

Its name comes from the indigenous word titirijí which means Moriche alluding to the species of palm that borders the entire lagoon and whose scientific name is Mauritia Flexuosa.

According to recent studies by some universities it is said that this ecosystem has 172 species of plants, among the most important for its ecosystem is the moriche palm. As for fauna 37 species of amphibians and reptiles, 41 mammals, 29 species of bats, 12 terrestrial, 229 species of birds, 48 species of ants, 25 species of cucarrones estercoleros and 100 species of fish.

pill.title: Tauramena: El Zambo waterfall
pill.content:
One of the attractions of Casanare is the Zambo waterfall. It is located in the municipality of Tauramena, in the middle of the Colombian Orinoquia, a magical land, perfect to disconnect from the world. Here you live in the middle of the transition of two worlds, the plains and the mountains. This place is ideal for bird watching, hiking and exploring the wonders of nature.

The Zambo waterfall is one of the most emblematic tourist attractions of Tauramena. Five vital ecosystems have been identified in this municipality, forests that protect fauna and water resources, and micro-watersheds that supply aqueducts. There are also the micro-watersheds of landscape incidence, wetlands and natural reserves.

It is a very visited site since it is relatively close to the urban area. The attractions of the site are, on the one hand, trekking to reach the Zambo waterfall and, on the other hand, the magnificent waterfall. For animal lovers, there is a great facility for wildlife watching. On the way to the waterfall you can enjoy the mountain and its landscape. There, the water springs in such a natural way that it bewilders and enchants.

gallery.title: How to get to the Zambo?

pill.title: Pore: Pauto river
pill.content:
The Pauto River rises in the paramo zone shared by the municipalities of Chita and Socotá, specifically in the Romeral moor or Alto de los Romeros at 3,700 meters above sea level in Socotá, Boyacá. It develops its course along the eastern flank of the eastern mountain range, until it reaches the plains foothills and the plain, at 300 meters above sea level. Its route begins in the municipality of Chita and ends in the Meta River in the town of Bocas del Pauto.

The basin is divided into 3 parts:

  • Upper basin: 3,700 - 2,000 m above sea level, 18% of the basin, in Boyacá
  • Middle basin: 2,000 - 350 masl, 27% of the basin
  • Lower basin: 350 - 150 m above sea level, 55% of the basin

The middle and lower basin of the Pauto river comprises part of the municipalities of: Tamara, Nunchia, Pore, Trinidad and San Luis de Palenque, in the department of Casanare. The Pauto River is one of the main tributaries of the Meta River, which in turn is an important tributary of the Orinoco River, the third most important river system in the world.

pill.title: Villanueva: Caño Arietes
pill.content:
Approximately 40 years ago the municipal aqueduct was built on this riverbed, which supplied water to the community of Villanueva through the installation of more than 100 rams and hoses. The rams were automatic pumps that were used to give power to the water. At that time two types of rams were installed in Villanueva: bell rams and arm rams. The noise of the pumping was so loud that it could be heard for several kilometers throughout the town. The history of the Caño Arietes is representative for the municipality and its inhabitants, since this is how the development of this beautiful land began.

Today, the ecological park Caño Arietes, is a spring full of water, with an abundance of flora and fauna, the well became a large natural pool where an artificial waterfall for recreation for locals and visitors, together with ecological trails and a totally natural environment. This attraction has been environmentally protected by the community, avoiding its contamination and inadequate manipulation.

gallery.title: When you visit Villanueva you have to go to this place

pill.title: Nature Reserve
pill.content:
Nature reserves are a specific type of protected area whose objective is the protection of wildlife (flora and/or fauna), ecosystems or spaces with ecological features that are of special interest and therefore deserve special consideration.

Nature reserves are managed by humans to protect them from damage and to prevent environmental degradation. The aim is to ensure good conservation of the area, as well as to provide opportunities for research and education.

The designation of these zones is governed by several principles:

  • The natural beauty of the area proposed as a protected area.
  • The scientific and educational interest of the region.
  • The preservation of natural areas that form the habitat of protected or endangered species.
  • That the region be considered a cultural heritage site.

gallery.title: Importance of Parks and Nature Reserves

pill.title: Aguazul: San Miguel de Farallones
pill.content:
The municipality of Aguazul is located in the northwest of the Orinoco region and covers a strip of the eastern cordillera of the Andes. Geologically, the cliffs are part of the foothills of the Eastern Cordillera. These imposing mountains are formed by soil bearings that gave rise to denuded hills, which formed the hills of San Miguel de Farallones.

In the Farallones de San Miguel, the vegetation corresponds to premontane rainforests and tropical forests. These two have a vital environmental value for the conservation of the natural balance of the ecosystem. In addition, there are springs and numerous bodies of water that feed the savannah.

In addition, these mountains are natural reserves that serve as habitat for numerous species of flora and fauna in transition between the mountains and the plains. In total, the Farallones de San Miguel has an area of 3,400 hectares.

First and foremost, Los Farallones de San Miguel is a protected area, oriented to contemplation. It is also intended for the recovery of flora and wildlife, and as an area that produces water and captures greenhouse gases.

pill.title: Paz de Ariporo: Zamaricote Hill
pill.content:
The Zamaricote hill, which is located in the jurisdiction of the municipalities of Paz de Ariporo, Pore and Támara, in the region of the plains foothills of the eastern mountain range in the department of Casanare. Zamaricote is a small mountain range, with an approximate expansion of 8,600 hectares and with an influence of 14,000 hectares isolated from the main mountain system of the eastern cordillera, "constituting the only independent water star of the fluvial network of the Andean system in Casanare". The main tributaries of the Ariporo and Guachiria rivers are born there, among others; and these feed the complex of the floodable savannahs of the municipalities of Hato Corozal and Paz de Ariporo (middle basin of the Ariporo and Guacharía rivers).

The ecosystems present in Zamaricote Hill provide services to small and medium producers in the municipalities of Paz de Ariporo, Pore and Támara, through the supply and regulation of water essential for irrigation, watering places and domestic consumption. Due to its location, it is decisive for the genetic exchange of flora and fauna between the savannah and the Andean zone given its location in the foothills. It is also an important carbon sink since it preserves a representative sample of forest ecosystems in a good state of conservation. On the other hand, given its environmental offer, Zamaricote hill becomes a strategic place for research, wildlife preservation, forest conservation and sustainable productive actions that contribute to improving the quality of life of its inhabitants.

pill.title: Civil society's natural reserves.
pill.content:
Civil Society Nature Reserves are a category of private protected area that make up the SINAP and are defined according to the legal framework (Decree 1076 of 2015) as "The part or the whole area of a property that conserves a sample of a natural ecosystem and is managed under the principles of sustainability in the use of natural resources".

The objective of the Reserves is the management of these areas under sustainability criteria that guarantee the conservation, preservation, regeneration or restoration of the natural ecosystems that are present in them and that allow the generation of environmental goods and services.

This category of protected area is characterized because it is an initiative of the owner of a property, who, in a free, voluntary and autonomous way, decides to destine all or part of his property as a Natural Reserve of the Civil Society.

Although since the 1970s there were people who had already committed to conservation on their land, the Civil Society Nature Reserves (RNSC) emerged as a form of private protection officially recognized in 1993. And, so far, through them, almost a thousand Colombians have been able to preserve part of the country's biodiversity in 192,698 hectares.

These spaces play a key role in conservation at local and regional scales, in regions where ecosystems are not sufficiently represented or are more degraded and fragmented, and are a fundamental part of the National System of Protected Areas.
