question.question: Where is San Miguel de Farallones located?

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

The Farallones mountain range is a strategic natural ecosystem of great importance for Casanare. This is due to its decisive role as a production and water recharge area for the Cusiana, Unete Chiquito and Seco rivers. A large number of tributaries originate there, such as the Aguablanca, Cacaguala, Caño Rico, Parásitos and Manoquía streams. In addition, the Los Algarrobos and El Recodo streams.

Another reason for the importance of the Farallones de San Miguel is that it is home to a large endemic fauna with an endangered species warning. Some of these species are the white-tailed deer, the chigüiro, the macaw, the armadillo or cachicamo. In addition to the charapa turtle, the llanero caiman, the water mouse, as well as different species of bats. Among the reptiles, the populations of crocodiles, babillas, babas, turtles, iguanas and lizards stand out. You can also see lizards, boas and a large number of venomous snakes.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content: Casanare has a great natural wealth and among it stands out the fauna, where we find diversity of birds, mammals, reptiles, fish and amphibians that give color and joy to the llanero landscapes; they also teach us their natural wealth through songs, courtship dances, care of their offspring and above all their role in the balance of nature. I invite you to learn about the importance of the Casanarean fauna in the preservation of ecosystems and as part of our llanero culture.

gallery.title: Casanare the heart of the plains

pill.title: Animals
pill.content: For thousands of years, humans have taken advantage of various species of animals for their own benefit, being cattle, horses and pack animals, essential in carrying out daily tasks. The work of the plains is an example of this, where the "llaneros" from very early in the morning begin their work of "vaquería" and that in recent times has become a tourist attraction, where visitors accompany the "llanero" and perform with him, this noble work.

pill.title: Animals
pill.content:
Horse

The scientific name of the horse is Equus ferus caballus, are known to mankind since ancient times, where they were initially domesticated and essential as a means of transport and other work in many cultures, are perissodactyl mammals (toes ending in hooves) whose embryonic development is about 11 months and the female has only one offspring per birth.

There are approximately 400 breeds of horses that specialize in different types of tasks; for example, in the llanero culture horses are fundamental, since they are strong, noble and resistant animals for the arduous work under the sun, the water, and the work of cowherding, being the faithful companion of the llanero in his day to day.

pill.title: Animals
pill.content:
Cattle

Cattle have a diversity of breeds, whose differences lie in their place of origin, physical characteristics and meat yield. In Colombia, due to its richness of territories, we can find cattle for meat production, dairy production or dual purpose depending on the breed and breeding intention.

In the plains of Casanare the most representative breeds are Gyr and Brahman, whose main purpose is dairy and meat production. We also find our own breed, the Creole Casanare, which unfortunately still does not have sufficient studies of its potential and is on the verge of disappearing due to successive crossbreeding.

pill.title: Animals
pill.content:
Beasts or mules

Mules are hybrids resulting from a cross between a donkey (male) and a mare (female horse) or the case of the hinnies, which are also mules, but come from a cross between a horse (male) and a female donkey.

Among their characteristics we find that most of them are sterile, they can be males or females and their physical appearance is very similar to that of a horse; they are animals of great physical strength and resistance to disease, for this reason they are ideal as an aid in the work of the plainsman.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content: Colombia is a megadiverse and privileged country due to its geographical location, which allows us to find a variety of climates conducive to the diversity of species. The Colombian fauna and especially the Casanareña fauna shows us multiple forms, adaptations to the environment, wonderful behaviors, genetic and natural wealth; among the most outstanding we have the chigüiros, toninas, otters, macaws, tapirs, jaguar, guacharacas, gabanes, coteras and cachicamo among others.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Small and medium-sized mammals

Chigüiro Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris

General characteristics: It is the largest rodent mammal in the world, herbivore with rough fur that varies from yellowish, reddish brown and dark brown, its weight in adulthood can be between 40 to 90 kg, depending on the place and food availability.

In Colombia it has several common names, for example, in Meta, Caquetá and Amazonas it is called capibara, the Tikunas in Amazonas call it copiwara and in Arauca and Casanare it is called Bocaeburro, culo pando and chigüire.

Habitat and reproduction: They are animals that live in herds, generally associated with bodies of water such as streams, lagoons, mangrove swamps associated with gallery forests, savannahs or grasslands, which gives them protection, food and shelter.

Their fertility is high and is associated with the fact that they are rodents and the availability of food; embryonic development lasts approximately 4 months and they have between 2 to 8 offspring per birth. As for parental care, it is present until the offspring are independent.

Importance: This species is considered of great ecological value because it acts as a biological controller of the excessive growth of vegetation and is a fundamental part of the trophic chains. At the economic level, it is a species of sustainable use through zoo farms, as long as they have the respective licenses for its operation.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Lapa Cuniculus paca

General characteristics: It is a medium-sized rodent mammal, weighs between 7 to 10 kg in adulthood, its fur is brown or orange with rounded white spots. It has many common names depending on the region where it is found, for example, boruga, guagua or paca. They are terrestrial habits, good swimmers and feed mainly on a variety of fruits, seeds, tubers, stems and leaves.

Habitat and reproduction: they are found in wooded, humid and mountainous environments, generally associated with bodies of water. Their gestation period varies from 114 to 118 days and generally only one calf is born per birth.

Importance: As their feeding habits are mainly frugivorous, they play a very important role in the dispersion of seeds of several types of plants; they also play a fundamental role in the trophic chains as prey for numerous species of carnivores such as the jaguar or the puma among others.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Cajuche Pecari tajacu

General characteristics: The cajuche has several common names among which are zaino, peccary or collared peccary. It is an artiodactyl mammal of medium size that lives in herds, grayish to brown fur with a whitish spot in the form of necklace neck; weigh between 20 to 30 kg and have a gland in the dorsal part that secretes a penetrating substance.

Habitat and reproduction: This species inhabits gallery forests, jungles and savannas, the latter ecosystem being the least frequent. Its diet consists of fruits, snails, invertebrates, small vertebrates, berries and tubers. The embryonic development lasts between 141 and 151 days approximately and 1 to 4 young are born per birth, which are weaned 3 to 4 months after birth.

Importance: They are animals of consumption for several populations in the region that benefit from the sale of their meat and oil, and it is said that their flavor is similar to that of pork, so the llaneros have developed strategies for their management and conservation.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Picure Dasyprocta fuliginosa

General characteristics: Another common name for this species is ñeque, it is a rodent mammal characterized by its reddish-brown fur and it can weigh from 2 to 3 kg. Like other mammals it makes burrows that it uses as shelter against possible predators.

Habitat and diet: It is found mainly in humid forests and scrublands, feeding on palm fruits, seeds, tubers, some herbs, flowers and insects.

Importance: They are animals with the habit of burying seeds as a reserve method for times of food shortage, but sometimes they do not find them again and these germinate into new palms and trees, which makes these rodents seed dispersers.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Saffron milkvetch Dasypus sabanicola

General characteristics: Also known as armadillo or cachicamo sabanero, it is a mammal that has little hair, but has an armour composed of 8 to 9 mobile plates that allow it to protect itself from predators; they have strong claws on their extremities that are used to dig their burrows and catch their prey. In adulthood they can weigh from 2 to 4 kg, they have short sight, but a good sense of smell.

Habitat and reproduction: It lives in scrublands, forests associated with bodies of water and savannahs. It is omnivorous, feeding on invertebrates, fruits and roots. The gestation period of the offspring is approximately 4 months and a curious fact about the offspring is that 4 males or 4 identical females are born.

Importance: It is an important predator of insect populations in the region.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Aquatic mammals

Commerson's dolphin Inia geoffrensis

General characteristics: They are cetacean mammals also known as pink dolphins, they feed on different types of fish, crabs and small turtles; their longevity is estimated between 30 and 40 years, they can measure approximately 2.8 meters and reach a weight of 180 kg.

They are currently on the verge of extinction, so it is essential to preserve them.

Habitat and reproduction: Commerson's dolphins inhabit the waters of rivers and lagoons in the Amazon and Orinoquia, their presence being, an indicator of clean waters in the area where they are found. They have a gestation period of 11 to 12 months and a single calf is born, which they take care of for several years.

Importance: This species is considered a biological controller of fish species and a regulator of the food chain. For example, it feeds on Caribbean fish that are predators of juveniles of other types of fish of commercial interest to local fishermen.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Manatees Trichechus manatus

General characteristics: Manatees are sirenian mammals whose body shape is robust, they have 3 fins, one caudal and two pectoral fins that facilitate their displacement in the water. Their nostrils are special, as they close when they submerge. Its size can vary between 2.5 and 4.5 meters and its weight can reach between 200 and 600 kg.

Habitat and diet: This species is found in bog systems, coastal waters, and freshwaters of the tropics and subtropics. They feed mainly on aquatic plants and sometimes also consume fish and invertebrates.

Importance: They play the role of nutrient recyclers in the ecosystem they inhabit, which contributes to the proliferation of plant and animal populations.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Large mammals

Otter Pteronura brasiliensis and Lontra longicaudis

General characteristics: Otters are carnivorous mammals associated with bodies of water. In the department of Casanare we find the giant otter (Pteronura brasiliensis) that can measure 1.5 to 2 meters including the tail, its fur is dark brown and has yellowish spots on the neck that differ from one individual to another; and the neotropical otter (Lontra longicaudis) that measures approximately between 90 cm and 1.40 meters whose fur is cinnamon brown to grayish brown with lighter spots on the belly and neck.

Habitat and Reproduction: These mammals have preferably clear bodies of water as their habitat, although they have also been observed in bodies of water with more sediment. Their gestation period can vary from 56 to 86 days according to research reports and observations in zoos; the number of offspring per birth can be from 1 to 5.

Importance: Considering the current transformation of aquatic ecosystems, otters become bio-indicators to monitor the ecological functionality of ecosystems, as they are animals that apparently inhabit little intervened water bodies.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Tapir Tapirus terrestris

General characteristics: The tapir is a large perissodactyl mammal, in adulthood can weigh between 150 to 250 kg, its fur is short blackish to brown and has a pronounced crest and short horn. It feeds on flowers and fruits and is a good swimmer.

Habitat and reproduction: This species occupies a great variety of habitats ranging from dry areas such as the guajira to the forests in the Amazon, passing through the savannas of the eastern plains, being important the presence of water bodies. As for the gestation time of 14 months and the birth is of a single calf that remains with the mother for approximately 2 years.

Importance: It is an excellent seed disperser and in the eastern plains it is important in the dispersion of the moriche palm Mauritia flexuosa.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Jaguar Phantera onca

General characteristics: This majestic mammal is considered the largest feline in America, its fur is yellow on the back with black spotted patterns unique to each individual, although sometimes you can find melanic individuals of black or brown coloration. Its weight can range between 40 and 90 kg depending on whether the individual is male or female.

Habitat and diet: Jaguars inhabit ecosystems such as tropical forests, mountain forests, tropical savannahs and mangroves. Being carnivorous felines, their diet is based on the consumption of meat from prey that they can stalk and hunt, such as peccaries, chigüiros and even caimans.

Importance: Being a predator that occupies a large territory, it is important in the control of populations of the species it consumes and the preservation of the ecosystems it inhabits.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Anteater Myrmecophaga tridactyla and Honey bear Tamandua tetradactyla

Characteristics and differences: These 2 species are generally known as anteaters, although we find well-marked differences such as size, the palm bear being larger, with rough fur between black, gray and white, and a tail with abundant hair that serves to cover itself at the time of rest; while the honey bear is much smaller, its coat color is yellow and thick and its tail has little hair.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Habitat and diet: These species are found in humid forests, rainforests and savannahs, they feed mainly on ants and termites that they catch with their long, sticky tongue after tearing ant hills and termite mounds with their claws; in the case of palm bears there are reports of consuming chizas or mojojoy and bee larvae.

Importance: As their diet is specialized, they become biological controllers of termite and ant populations.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Reptiles

Turtles

Turtles are a group of chelonian reptiles, characterized by a shell that covers and protects their internal organs, and where they can hide their limbs and head to defend themselves from predators. They are oviparous, and dig their nests in the ground to incubate their eggs. They do not have teeth, but they have a strong beak to capture their prey, which can be fish, plants, insects and worms depending on the tastes of each species. They are long-lived animals that can live between 50 and 80 years.

In Casanare the most representative species are:

Morrocoy: Chelonoidis carbonaria

Its carapace is black or dark brown, with orange-reddish spots or yellow-orange spots, they can measure between 30 and 35 cm in length.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Galapaga or savanna: Podocnemis vogli

Its shell can vary from light brown to olive green with a smooth texture and oval shape. Its size can range from 17 to 36 cm in length, with females reaching the largest size.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Hicotea: Trachemis callirostris

Its carapace is green with black spots on the marginal scales and the head is olive green, with yellow longitudinal lines and yellow spots on the chin and jaw. This species does not exceed 35 cm in adulthood.

Humans have generated a drastic decrease in the populations of these turtle species, increasing their risk of extinction, either by hunting, consumption of their eggs, sale of hatchlings as pets and damage to their habitat.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Caiman llanero Crocodylus intermedius and Cachirre Paleosuchus trigonatus

These reptiles are of great ecological importance since, as predators, they play a fundamental role in the flow of energy in the ecosystem they inhabit, which is generally associated with bodies of water, and they also exercise biological control over the species they consume.

The llanero caiman is one of the largest crocodiles in the world and is located in the Orinoco basin between Colombia and Venezuela.

Its population has been drastically affected by indiscriminate hunting for its skin and meat consumption.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content: On the other hand, the smaller cachirre is considered the second smallest crocodilian in the world, its diet is composed of invertebrates and small vertebrates that it hunts either in the water or on land.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Eunectes murinus and Boa constrictor guinea pigs

The black guio or anaconda (Eunectes murinus) and the Boa constrictor (Boa constrictor) are constrictor snakes, which means that they constrict their prey with the strength of their bodies when capturing them, since they do not have venom. They can reach a large size and for this reason they are known and representative in the eastern plains. They are found in the wooded savannahs, swamps and near water sources for their displacement since they are good swimmers.

The main characteristic of the anaconda is its large size, as it can weigh up to 250 kg and measure approximately 9 meters. Its body is olive in color with oval-shaped black spots on the back and black spots with ochre on the sides of its body.

The coloration of the dorsal side of the guio is grey with brown or lighter spots on the inside. They can reach up to 5.5 m in length depending on food availability or the sex of the animal.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Birds are a group of vertebrate animals found in most ecosystems of the planet, they are characterized by the presence of feathers, beak and legs usually with claws depending on the type of food and taxonomic classification. They are numerous and diverse in terms of size, coloration, feeding habits and behavior.

Ecologically they play a very important role, since we find birds that disperse seeds, recycle and transform waste and control biological species. In Casanare inhabit diversity of birds that unfortunately face threat to their survival due to the destruction, fragmentation of their habitat and depending on the species human consumption.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Herons

The herons are a group of stylized and representative birds of Casanare, within which you can find several species such as the brown heron Ardea cocoi, the grey heron Ardea alba, the blue heron Egretta caeruela and the corocora Eudocimus ruber among others. Heron feeding is based on fish consumption and we can find them resting in groups of different species in the same place.

Brown heron: inhabits savannas, marshes and gallery forests near bodies of water.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: Grey heron: It can be found in savannas, marshes and edges of gallery forests.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: Blue heron: This species is found in savannas, marshes and gallery forests.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: Corocora: This bird is found in the natural savannah and also consumes insects as part of its diet.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Red-billed Curassow Ortalis ruficauda

This bird of diurnal habits is common in the region, generally groups of up to 6 individuals are observed vocalizing noisily in the gallery forests and stubble areas.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Aruco Anhima cornuta

This bird of diurnal habits is associated with bodies of water such as rivers, lagoons, marshes and estuaries, its diet is based on floating vegetation of the places it inhabits; they can be found in groups of up to 5 individuals.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Gaboon Cicconia maguari and Mycteria americana

The Pioneer stork Cicconia maguari and the American stork Mycteria americana are diurnal birds that can be seen in open savannahs or marshes, although the Pioneer stork is only seen at certain times of the year. They feed on aquatic invertebrates and small terrestrial vertebrates.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Ducks

In the region you can find several species of ducks such as the Brazilian duck Amazonetta brasiliensis, Pato güiriri Dendrocygna viduata and duck Neochen jubata. These species are diurnal and their diet is based on vegetation and small invertebrates.

The Brazilian duck is found in marshes and flooded savannahs in groups of up to 20 individuals.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: The güiriri duck is associated with bodies of water such as rivers, marshes, swamps and wetlands, and flocks of more than 1,000 individuals can be found in summer.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: The wigeon is found mainly in flooded savannas and estuaries in flocks of approximately 2,000 or more individuals.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Chenchena Opisthocomus hoazin

This species has several common names such as pava hedionda, serere and hoatzin among others. It inhabits the interior of gallery forests always associated with bodies of water. It has both diurnal and nocturnal habits and can feed on leaves and fruits. It presents noisy vocalizations of various types, which makes it even more striking.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Crax alberti willow

The size of this bird ranges between 80 and 90 cm in length, it lives in forests and can be observed in any forest stratum. It feeds on seeds, insects, flowers, fruits, worms, large arthropods and others and plays an important role in seed dispersal.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Coteras Aramides cajaneus

Also known as chilacoa and for its song during the whole day, it lives in the gallery forests, being its main food invertebrates. Its habits can be both diurnal and nocturnal.

question.question: The animals that are used as support in the plain work are:

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

All over the world the different species of fauna have many common names, but their scientific name is universal...

for example, the anteater is known as the anteater, yurumi, tamandua flag and this can lead to confusion when identifying a species...

But if we say Myrmecophaga tridactyla everywhere it lives it will be more easily identified without any doubt or confusion.

posts.title: The alligator toom
posts.description: It tells the story of the caiman toom, an old and gigantic specimen that protects its eggs day and night from the terrible human claws, so that they can know the wonderful life that the tributary of the Orinoco offers them.

posts.title: Capybara mama and the plains drought
posts.description: During the year, mother capybara and her children enjoy their life in the vicinity of the Pauto river, but the long arm of pollution and destruction has reached their home, now they must flee and find a new home for their children, lives the story of Capybara mom, our heroine.

posts.title: Lola, the drama of a mother
posts.description: Lola, the otter and her children are threatened when a group of animal traffickers arrives on the river bank, who, upon realizing the presence of the otters, see the possibility of selling them to earn money.

posts.title: The aardvark super hero
posts.description: "Samy" is a very outgoing anteater who lives happily with his mother but he wants to find new friends so he can have fun in the pond, but this fun is obstructed by the problems that his species and its habitat live due to the evil actions of man. and the monster "petroleum".

posts.title: What are we mom?
posts.description: Faced with the disturbing question of her children, the woolly chucha responds and argues about the identity of their species and the importance they are for the ecosystem.

posts.title: Forest olympics
posts.description: The story takes place in the forest where all the tapirs once a year met to do their diving competitions and decide who was the best, the winner gave them various seeds to eat and plant and thus counteract the felling of trees.

posts.title: Branches of the trade
posts.description: Yaki is one of the few night monkeys whose family is still complete and reunited; despite the stalking scientists and the continuous fighting between legal and illegal armed groups.

posts.title: Man stains
posts.description: Othello seems to be used to eating the animals of a nearby farm, the owner although annoying, limits himself to scare him away, but a hunter offers to get rid of the 'problem' at no cost, in the end due to the circumstances the farmer recognizes that it is not the fault of the animal, but of those who invade their environment.

posts.title: No hunting, like at home
posts.description: Kata is a lonely limpet and with traumas of course abandonment, she was too young to understand the circumstances in which her parents died at the hands of hunters, escaping from one of them she finds her partner and with whom they will persevere so as not to let her your species is eradicated.

posts.title: Slow leak, quick conclusion
posts.description: We have Roko on the scene, a male long-nosed turtle whose hobby is ... letting time go by. In one of his routines he is found by a group of indigenous people who capture him and reunite with others of the same species. One of them warns him about his destiny: to be merchandise or food.

posts.title: Harmful protection
posts.description: Totema is a cunning, persistent and brave turtle, but that will not reach him until he realizes that his fight has an end.

posts.title: Grandma Goose
posts.description: "Every day an old goose sees how her environment changes, and the poor little geese have to adapt to the changes that damage their ecosystem and their way of life, read the stories of Leonor the older goose."

posts.title: Free of flown
posts.description: Xalma is caged in a truck about to be sold. From her confinement, she tells us her story without suspecting that she will have a positive outcome, although only for her.

posts.title: What we parrots talk about
posts.description: It tells how an obese parrot got to this condition due to the irresponsible care of human beings. A contradictory way to conserve the species, as deforestation has led these creatures to reduce their numbers.

posts.title: On someone else's skin
posts.description: Tasko is a pollero wolf, a lizard with a great appetite and a confident character. Initially, he is stressed at the thought that he was abandoned by his family, but he will discover thanks to an old friendship that his children did not leave voluntarily, but instead became articles of clothing and fashion accessories for unconcerned people.

posts.title: Teacher Pepperan
posts.description: "In each school day the teacher Pepperan teleported his students to times ago with his great and funny stories"

posts.title: Path of roses, glorious birds
posts.description: It is not enough for this striking specimen called Rozz to stand out, however, of its striking plumage and advantage to find food thanks to its spoon / spatula-shaped beak. but the wild life is raw and he must take it on with his characteristic good attitude.

posts.title: Robbed thief, and his world ended
posts.description: The soldier garzon is a huge bird whose reputation as a predator is well known among those who have been the victims of its attacks. Iguaro will now discover that while he was stealing prey, he and all the birds were stealing their trees.

posts.title: Until it's over
posts.description: A group of deer that feed are ambushed by hunters who set fire to the area to confuse them, in the flight the youngest fall into the hands of men, which forces Azel to return, the young men manage to flee, but Azel stays in his replacement.

posts.title: Red-hot celebration
posts.description: Ibis is an ordinary corocora, but it knows well what is good for it. When he realizes the evil that humans cause, he decides to simply leave, forming part of the migration statistics that report the red ibis as displaced from its habitat.

posts.title: Before and after, here was a fish
posts.description: There are no protagonists here, but there are antagonists depending on the point of view. The payara is feared for its ferocity and voracious appetite, but who the real monster is will soon be revealed. Man is killing this species due to overfishing.

posts.title: Healthy prj mavera
posts.description: On this occasion we will be guided by animals that interact with plants. Cayenne is a plant whose flower serves multiple health benefits.

posts.title: Fruit of exploitation
posts.description: Some travelers (known as backpackers) get lost in the jungles of the Orinoco and decide to use nearby palms to guarantee survival. In an exaggerated way for narrative sake, they build all kinds of items and prepare some foods. Finally the reflection aims to be responsible and respectful with the use of this plant.

posts.title: Oranges in the air
posts.description: There is nothing to worry about, the palo de cruz tree proliferates and its abundance benefits its environment. Polena will limit herself to discovering one of the most remarkable aspects of this species: its reproductive phase, at the end it will throw some pistils into the air inviting them to enjoy this flower.

posts.title: Wood in sunset
posts.description: A sad beginning, a knot that does not improve and an ending that gives hope. Logging kills the trees.

posts.title: Go up like palm ... and there it stays
posts.description: Here there will only be good omen, abundance and well-being. The corozo palm is a stable species and under good care.

posts.title: Craftiness? pure straw
posts.description: A plant whose flower pollen does not like? This seems to be the case, since it is a sporiferous plant. But is she bad enough to talk about her?
